name: Path T Corpus Sarcoma
title: Pathologic T
notes:
**Note 1:**  When both FIGO stage and extension detail are available, record the code with extension detail in preference to a statement of FIGO stage.

**Note 2:**   TNM and FIGO do not include an in situ category for corpus sarcoma tumors. Assign 88 and behavior code /2 for in situ tumors.

**Note 3:** Tumor size must be known to assign a value of T1a or T1b. You may use a physicianâs statement of the T category if this is the only information in the medical record. If the tumor appears to be in the T1 category, but no size or category is specified, assign T1,

**Note 4:**  FIGO Stage IV, NOS is assigned based on tumor extension and/or metastasis.  Code primary tumor based on a physician's statement of FIGO Stage IV, NOS only if it is known that the stage value is assigned because of tumor extension.
footnotes:
\*TX is not defined by UICC in the 7th edition. Approval has been provided by UICC to use the standard definition "Primary tumor cannot be assessed," as TX.
**T0 is not defined by UICC in the 7th edition. Approval has been provided by UICC to use the standard definition "No evidence of primary tumor," as T0.
rows:
Surgical resection of primary tumor done and extension not stated or unknown
Surgical resection of primary tumor done and extension not documented in patient record
Surgical resection of primary tumor done, size is part of the T definition and the size is not available but information states that the tumor is confined to the primary

Note: T1 has subcategories of T1a and T1b. Assign T1 only when there is no information available to assign one of the subcategories

Tumor limited to uterus, NOS
Invasive cancer tumor confined to corpus uteri
Invasion of myometrium, NOS
Localized, NOS

Tunica serosa of the visceral peritoneum (serosa covering the corpus)

Endocervical glandular involvement only

Cervical stromal invasion

Cervix uteri, NOS, but not beyond uterus

FIGO Stage I [NOS]

Stated as T1 [NOS]
Tumor 5 cm or less in greatest dimension

Invasive cancer tumor confined to corpus uteri 
Confined to endometrium (stroma)

Tumor invades less than one-half of myometrium
Invasion of inner half of myometrium

FIGO Stage IA

Stated as T1a
Tumor more than 5 cm in greatest dimension

Tumor invades one-half or more of myometrium
Invasion of outer half of myometrium

FIGO Stage IB

Stated as T1b
Tumor extends beyond the uterus, within the pelvis

Note: T2 has subcategories of T2a and T2b. Assign T2 only when there is no information available to assign one of the subcategories

FIGO Stage II [NOS]

Stated as T2 [NOS]

Adnexal involvement, NOS
Extension or metastasis beyond uterus within pelvis:
    Adnexa
    Fallopian tube(s)
    Ligaments:
        Broad
        Round
        Uterosacral
    Ovary(ies)
    Parametrium
    Visceral peritoneum of pelvic organs excluding serosa of corpus uteri

FIGO Stage IIA

Stated as T2a

Extension to :
    Ureter
    Vulva

Extension or metastasis to:
    Cul de sac (rectouterine pouch)   
    Parietal serosa of pelvic cavity
    Pelvic wall(s)
    Vagina

Described clinically as "frozen pelvis", NOS

FIGO Stage IIB

Stated as T2b

Note: T3 has subcategories of T3a and T3b. Assign T3 only when there is no information available to assign one of the subcategories

FIGO Stage III [ NOS]

Stated as T3 [NOS]

Infiltration of abdominal tissues, one of the following sites:
    Abdominal serosa (visceral or parietal peritoneum of abdomen)
    Sigmoid colon
    Small intestine
    Other abdominal tissues

FIGO Stage IIIA

Stated as T3a

FIGO Stage IIIB

Stated as T3b
Tumor invades bladder or rectal mucosa

Invasion of:
    Bladder wall
    Bladder, NOS excluding mucosa
    Rectal wall
    Rectum, NOS excluding mucosa

Extension to bowel mucosa or bladder (excluding bullous edema)

Further contiguous extension

FIGO Stage IVA
FIGO Stage IV [NOS] based on extension

Stated as T4

Pathologic T is not defined for the specific site/histology
In situ case but no pTis is defined by TNM

No pathologic evaluation of primary tumor
No surgical resection of primary tumor and there isn't a positive biopsy of the highest T
Only positive biopsy of tumor which is not the highest T 
Unknown if any pathologic assessment performed
